channel.title: Sequoia McDowell's Blog Feed
channel.description: Occassional posts about web programming, software engineering, and JavaScript.

item.title: A Fond Farewell to My Greatest Fans
item.description: I am removing the comment forms from my website due to spam. But are spam comments all bad? Not necessarily! Some of my best comments have been spam.

item.title: Two Painful Ways to Misuse JavaScript's Symbol Descriptions
item.description: ES2019 introduced a new way to access the (non-unique) description property of (unique) Symbol objects. As with any new JS feature, every developer's first question is "how can I shoot myself in the foot with this?" Read and find out!

item.title: Avoiding Ticket Scope Creep While Improving Code
item.description: We all want to "improve as we go" when writing code, but how do we do this while also getting the feature development task at hand done and keeping our PRs small?

item.title: When to Use a Programming Framework
item.description: Frameworks are good when they speed up stuff you already know how to do; if they are just magic incantations and you have no idea what theyâ€™re actually doing, thatâ€™s when you run into trouble.

item.title: The Rabbi and the Open Source Project
item.description: A rabbi, an Ã©lite open source project maintainer, and a workaday developer walk into a tech conference

item.title: Conference Tips
item.description: Some thoughts on getting the most out of tech conferences.

item.title: Session Management with Microservices
item.description: Microservices make some tasks easier and introduce some challenges where they didn't exist before. In this post we'll look at sharing sessions across microservices on the `now` platform.

item.title: What is "JavaScript?" Part 2: Solutions
item.description: "Bleeding edge" is all well and good, but can't we at least opt-in? Here's one weird trick to bring some transparency into the JavaScript module ecosystem with regard to new language featuresâ€¦

item.title: What is "JavaScript?" Part 1: The Problem
item.description: In the age of Babel, babel-plugins, and widespread transpilation, what does it mean for something to be JavaScript, and why does that question matter?

item.title: Let's Code It: Static Site Generator with Rx.js
item.description: Watching a filesystem for changes and building an input (markdown) file to output (HTML) on each change? This sounds like a job for... Observables!

item.title: Let's Code It: Static Site Generator
item.description: Markdown in, HTML out... do we really need a framework for this? I Don't Think So!!

item.title: Interactive Debugging with Node.js
item.description: Interactive Debuggers are familiar to every Java developer, but they are much less well known in the JavaScript world. If you're a JavaScript developer who hasn't experienced the power of step-thru debugging, read this post to find out what you're missing!

item.title: The Node.js Debug Module: Advanced Usage
item.description: So you're familiar with the `debug` node module. Let's take a look at some more advanced uses and useful tricks!

item.title: Let's Code It: The `debug` Module
item.description: What if, instead of commenting out or deleting our useful log statements when we're not using them, we could turn them on when we need them and off when we don't? The `debug` module lets us do that-- but how does it work? Let's find out!

item.title: Type Hinting in JavaScipt
item.description: What type is this object, what properties does it have, what arguments does this function take... there's a lot I don't miss about writing Java full-time, but boy do I miss this! Can we get these type hints in JavaScript? Let's find out!

item.title: Techniques to Avoid Live Coding, Part 1
item.description: The demo-gods are unmerciful and typing is hard with hundreds of people looking on. Learn to write code without writing code and your presentations will go off without a hitch!

item.title: Migrating a Legacy System to a Modern API Framework
item.description: LoopBack makes it easy to develop greenfield APIs, but in real business environments, data isnâ€™t always tidy & cooperative. In this case study we'll see what it takes to migrate a complex legacy application to LoopBack.

item.title: Higher Order Functions in ES6: Easy as a => b => c;
item.description: New language features can make an expression that was cumbersome to write in ES5 easy in ES6, enabling and encouraging the use of this type of expression. Weâ€™re going to look at one such case here: how arrow functions make it easier to write higher-order functions in ES6.

item.title: Building to Github Pages with Grunt
item.description: Wherein I document my Grunt+github-pages+bookmarklet build which required templating, switching branches, rebasing, commit, and all sorts of craziness.

item.title: Fun With Toilet
item.description: Shell feeling shabby? Spice things up with Toilet, the ASCII generator!

item.title: LoLshield Sequencer
item.description: How do you encode animations for a 9x14 LED matrix? By building a web-app, of course!
